website_summaries.verdict: A great field guide for insects of North America with a lot of information on how-to find, identify, and collect.
pros: Very handy and easy to use
Professional enough for entomologists, but easy enough for anyone interested in learning more about insects
cons: Does not have as much color as some of the other field guides

customer_reviews.title: Good adult resource.
customer_reviews.text: Unfortunately, I bought this to share with my grandchildren and there are not very many color plates and it is too much work to be practical for them. They are just starting school.
customer_reviews.author: r busy b

customer_reviews.title: This book was missing a part.
customer_reviews.text: oops! I got the book for my class to learn to use a dichotomous key for identification. The key in this book begins in the front outpapers and is supposed to continue in the back outpapers. Unfortunately the back outpapers are completely blank, rendering the book less than useable. I don't know if it is a single misprint or a larger problem but I'm returning this one.
customer_reviews.author: Victor Young

customer_reviews.title: I love this guide
customer_reviews.text: I love this guide. One of the best for insects, this definitely enhanced my learning experience in my entomology course. And now I find myself keeping this book in my bag everywhere I go. Really handy. With insects, you need to take a taxonomic approach to identify between families, this book lays out the differences for easier id. (In some scenarios a magnifying glass or dissecting scope is the most helpful.)
customer_reviews.author: Delaney

customer_reviews.title: Not user friendly
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for my grandson and it was very disappointing. This book, at best, would be suitable for an entomologist. Terms aren't well defined. Diagrams to general. Hard to find where to start if you see an insect you want to identify. He hasn't used it once.
customer_reviews.author: SEL

customer_reviews.title: I'd like more color plates (there are 16) but the B&W ...
customer_reviews.text: Bought this one because it's part of the Peterson series. Voluminous technical text, LOL, but that's the nature of the beast. I'd like more color plates (there are 16) but the B&W illustrations are decent and use the "diagnostic" arrows to point out significant features. I recommend it, but it's not as "easy" as Peterson's Eastern birds book. :-)
customer_reviews.author: Leslie E. Woolner

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for school
customer_reviews.text: This was perfect for my 9-yr old in 4th grade. They were studying insects for this year and this gave him more than enough materials to build a realistic insect model. My son loved this book and read it avidly before building his insect model. Great purchase for us!
customer_reviews.author: Frenchman in Boston

customer_reviews.title: great educational book
customer_reviews.text: My girlfriend is studying to be a forensic entomologist and she had been wanting to purchase this book for awhile, so i ended up buying it for her birthday. She loves it and uses it in her studies. I would suggest the purchase for that bug enthusiast in your life.
customer_reviews.author: Cherelle A. Becerra

customer_reviews.title: Nice field handbook
customer_reviews.text: Decent price for a book I have been wanting for a while. I have Borr's ID book but it is too big to take to the field. This is a nice hand book that I can take to the field and it has comparable information....not the most complete but very broad for it being a handbook. Overall, I am happy.
customer_reviews.author: Jesus Corona

customer_reviews.title: ... are older (somewhat out of date) these guides are great to me
customer_reviews.text: I have all of these series of field guides and even though they are older (somewhat out of date) these guides are great to me.
customer_reviews.author: Axiom Appellant

customer_reviews.title: Great book, as most of the Peterson Field Guides ...
customer_reviews.text: Great book, as most of the Peterson Field Guides are. Lots of information, from how insects are classified to descriptions of certain bugs. Very good book, super useful to learn from.
customer_reviews.author: nathan

customer_reviews.title: A classic field guide at an excellent price.
customer_reviews.text: Despite being published several decades ago, this field guide is a current must have for any northeasterner interested in amature entomology. Its construction is durable and it's full of wonderful illustrations and short descriptions that will have you identifying insects in no time! The front and back covers even have a convientent, illustrated dichotomous key that can help you get started by determining the order of your mystery insect.
customer_reviews.author: Manda Rae

customer_reviews.title: Ok, not great.
customer_reviews.text: Not a bad book, but has line drawings rather than photos. Ordered in error, meant to order the National Wildlife Federation Field Guide to Insects. (Ordered that one, will return this one.)
customer_reviews.author: Joyce G.

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: great book, has all the info needed to satisfy curiosity. Bought for my daughter, 14, she uses it daily.
customer_reviews.author: Robert Johnston

customer_reviews.title: Lots of good information
customer_reviews.text: I garden extensively and wanted to be able to identify insects on my plants. Unfortunately, there are too many insects to allow all or even most of them to be illustrated in one book. At best, this book will get you to genus. I could not even get to genus on most of them. It's not as useful as I had hoped. The illustrations that are shown are excellent.
customer_reviews.author: ChiLuvr

customer_reviews.title: Okay, but there are better alternatives
customer_reviews.text: This is a good field guide, but there are no color pictures, and the labeling system assumes that you already have a knowledge of the insect families. I bought this for an entomology class, but didn't use it once throughout the semester. I would recommend the Audubon guide (also available on Amazon) as a better alternative.
customer_reviews.author: Cameron

customer_reviews.title: Field guide to Insects
customer_reviews.text: Some of the taxonomy is out of date, some orders and families have changed since the book was published, but its still very useful when identifying insects. There are several illustrations of many of the common species including the colored plates. I used it several times while making a collection for an entomology class and was really glad I had it.
customer_reviews.author: Natalie Hernandez

customer_reviews.title: Great gift!
customer_reviews.text: Bought this book for a friend who studies insects and he loved it
customer_reviews.author: Jesse

customer_reviews.title: ... book has an area full of photo's that they enjoyed going through
customer_reviews.text: There is a ton of writing in this book which may have been to advanced for my nephews but the center of the book has an area full of photo's that they enjoyed going through.
customer_reviews.author: Joe

customer_reviews.title: It is a useful book. Pretty much what I expected
customer_reviews.text: It is a useful book. Pretty much what I expected. It arrived quickly and in good condition.
customer_reviews.author: Daniel Hemesath

customer_reviews.title: Great Field Guide
customer_reviews.text: This is a very helpful book for identifying insects. However, some of the taxonomy is out of date, so you have to check again with another source.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Still recommend to have as part of your field guide
customer_reviews.text: 4 stars because the book is mostly out of date on the larger groupings of Insecta but the info on the families are for the most part correct. Still recommend to have as part of your field guide collection
customer_reviews.author: scarlet a.m.

customer_reviews.title: ... class that I need this for its been a great field guide
customer_reviews.text: Taking a class that I need this for its been a great field guide.
customer_reviews.author: jason spillett

customer_reviews.title: Not enough detail.
customer_reviews.text: Tried to look up 2 insects that i found.Could not find either one of them in the book.Either this book was published many years ago or they just didn't list all the insects that you will find in North America.Would not recommend this book.
customer_reviews.author: James R. Shireman

customer_reviews.title: Great Book for quick reference
customer_reviews.text: I got this book because of a class I am taking at UW. It helps me to identify the insects very quickly when I'm out in the field collecting. This way I don't have to haul around my text book
customer_reviews.author: SAS

customer_reviews.title: A great goose for identifying bugs
customer_reviews.text: A great goose for identifying bugs. It has a dichotomous Key in the covets that helps you get on the right track with your identification.
customer_reviews.author: Science Teacher

customer_reviews.title: Does the job!
customer_reviews.text: No complaints. A great book for my Forensic Entomology course at university.
customer_reviews.author: Chelsea Coppock

customer_reviews.title: great field guide
customer_reviews.text: I love the Peterson series field guides, I now have almost all of them and they ate accurate and interesting to say the least. My grandkids love to look up all the bugs they see at our cabin.
customer_reviews.author: Tom T

customer_reviews.title: but still good
customer_reviews.text: Could use a little more information, but still good book
customer_reviews.author: sherry a haug

customer_reviews.title: Great ID guide for insects
customer_reviews.text: Great ID guide for insects, I am still using this years after taking an entomology class where this book was helpful in the field.
customer_reviews.author: MumblerK

customer_reviews.title: Would recommend to anyone who wants to know what they have ...
customer_reviews.text: Would recommend to anyone who wants to know what they have come across, and need to identify what insect they have. Also has info on how to preserve and display insect.
customer_reviews.author: Bill Manke

customer_reviews.title: I am having trouble finding pictures and description of some ...
customer_reviews.text: I am having trouble finding pictures and description of some of the bugs I see but will probably eventually find them.
customer_reviews.author: homesteader finally

customer_reviews.title: Good reference
customer_reviews.text: Great reference and nice photos. Very easy to use. I would recommend this for anyone interested in exploring the insects in their backyard.
customer_reviews.author: T. Ferguson

customer_reviews.title: Don't look at it as much as I thought I would.
customer_reviews.text: Was just looking to identify some of the insects that I see from time to time. Not a favorite subject but I'd like to know what's bitting me. I tried to check some of them out but it was more trouble than it was worth. Didn't know too much about such but thought it might be interesting. In a different subject matter I might have liked it better.
customer_reviews.author: Charles F. Tumeo Jr

customer_reviews.title: This was not as useful for identifying unknown species as it could have been
customer_reviews.text: The main problem with insect books is that there are hundreds of thousands of species and any book can only cover a small sampling. Other than 16 color plate pages, all the illustrations are black and white drawings. This was not as useful for identifying unknown species as it could have been.
customer_reviews.author: B. Kirkpatrick

customer_reviews.title: Best Available
customer_reviews.text: Though the copyright content is getting dating, it's still one of the better books of it's sort out there for the more informed.
customer_reviews.author: Larry Trone

customer_reviews.title: Decent
customer_reviews.text: For some reason it took forever to get, but other than that, it's a good purchase to add to your collection of field guides. It's best to use this one with other field guides, (such as Kaufman's) because the pictures aren't that great (when there are some) but the text is more detailed.
customer_reviews.author: Henry

customer_reviews.title: Insects.
customer_reviews.text: Purchased through Amazon and just what I wanted. Product was delivered in time for Christmas and the recipient was very pleased. So was I.
customer_reviews.author: P. Holladay

customer_reviews.title: good reference book
customer_reviews.text: I use this book all the time and would buy again thanks, it was at a great deal too ..
customer_reviews.author: Dc

customer_reviews.title: Great insect id text
customer_reviews.text: Awesome field guide for insect identification. Highly recommended by many including myself. Will continue to use this past entomology class!
customer_reviews.author: TaylorYerrick

customer_reviews.title: Very Weak on Pictures
customer_reviews.text: When I purchased this book I expected a "National Audubon" type field guide with many color pictures of insects. Instead it was quit thin and only show certain insect groups in color pictures. Extremely disappointed! I guess I should have stuck with Audubon field guides but I thought Peterson guides would be even more extensive. I was wrong! I'll never doubt again.
customer_reviews.author: GuitarPlayer

customer_reviews.title: not what I was looking for
customer_reviews.text: was not at all what I was looking for if I was in store and look in it I would not have bought it
customer_reviews.author: JACK

customer_reviews.title: Not bad
customer_reviews.text: A little more complex than wanted but still very informative. Useful reference for your average insect enthusisast just wanting an identification.
customer_reviews.author: Brian Kuehl

customer_reviews.title: Great guide!
customer_reviews.text: Great guide! Peterson field guides are well organized and thought out! Could use a few more color photos but still a great reference guide as is.
customer_reviews.author: ck3500ton

customer_reviews.title: Sometimes the old stuff is the best.
customer_reviews.text: Excellent reference. The flow charts inside the front and back covers make it easy to find your bug. Easier to use that some of the newer references.
customer_reviews.author: Daedalis

customer_reviews.title: Very good for class
customer_reviews.text: Had to buy this book for my arthropod class and it has been very helpful so far. Good reference book for visuals, classification and general vocabulary.
customer_reviews.author: Carlos Eduardo Ramirez

customer_reviews.title: Good Guide
customer_reviews.text: I am always a fan of the Peterson Field Guides. They are always well laid out and easy to understand. I especially love the arrows pointing to the distinct characteristics that separate the insect families in this guide. Very pleased.
customer_reviews.author: Bsel08

customer_reviews.title: PETERSONS FIELD GUIDES ROCK !
customer_reviews.text: IM SUCH A DUMB GRISTLE HEADED COWBOY ! I KILLED A SPIDER IN MY HOUSE ONE NIGHT . IVE GOT TO KNOW WHAT KIND OF CRITTER THAT IS . PETERSONS FIELD GUIDES . YUP ! GOT MY BOOK IN THE MAIL . CANT WAIT TO IDENTIFY THAT SPIDER . HOLY CROW ! SPIDERS ARENT INSECTS . PETERSONS FIELD GUIDES ROCK THO . NOW I GET TO ORDER A SPIDER BOOK .YEE HAW ! THE INSECT BOOK IS A DERN GOOD BOOK THO . GREM LEE
customer_reviews.author: Oliver (Grem) Lee

customer_reviews.title: the new (used) book is in excellent condition!
customer_reviews.text: cant wait to go out and catch some bugs. the new (used) book is in excellent condition!
customer_reviews.author: Melissa

customer_reviews.title: Recieved
customer_reviews.text: Got it on time and in perfect condition. The book is as shown on the website and is what is was listed as
customer_reviews.author: James

customer_reviews.title: Bugbook
customer_reviews.text: A nice book but not enough pictures of insects. Perhaps they should break it down in to smaller regions since there are so many differnt bugs!
customer_reviews.author: Sally S. Eynon

customer_reviews.title: Lack of color makes this virtually useless
customer_reviews.text: Although this book certainly appears to be detailed and comprehensive, its lack of color photos (there's a single, small section) makes it less than useful. Want to identify that iridescent green bug? Good luck -- this won't help much. The Nat'l Audubon Society's book might be a better bet.
customer_reviews.author: Andrew Kantor

customer_reviews.title: Handy Identification tool
customer_reviews.text: Compact little guide and very useful in the field and in the laboratory. Students find the book easy to use.
customer_reviews.author: Helene

customer_reviews.title: ... whole guide is in black and white - not useful.
customer_reviews.text: Almost the whole guide is in black and white - not useful.
customer_reviews.author: Nancy Desch

customer_reviews.title: Field Guide to Insects
customer_reviews.text: I have used this book many times in my entomology courses. This time, I ordered 2 copies to give as gifts. As usual, your Amazon.com service was excellent. Keep up the good work for us satisfied customers. Dr. Daniel J. Sullivan Professor - Dept. Biological Sciences Fordham University Bronx, NY 10458
customer_reviews.author: Dr. Daniel J. Sullivan

customer_reviews.title: Excelent!
customer_reviews.text: As mentioned by other reviewers, this field guide is amazing. The paper and printing quality is an A+. And no to mention exceptionally good wrapping and delivery from Amazon.
customer_reviews.author: Kai

customer_reviews.title: The fit was really inaccurate (too big) and these are ...
customer_reviews.text: The fit was really inaccurate (too big) and these are straight leg not skinny. .I repeat. . NOT SKINNY. I washed them hoping they would shrink. THEY DIDN'T. SOOOO DISAPPOINTED
customer_reviews.author: ed

product_meta.title: A Field Guide to Insects: America North of Mexico (Peterson Field Guides)
